case_vignette: A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my right eye about half an hour ago while I was watching TV.
Have you experienced any headache or pain in the eye before the vision loss?
No, there was no pain when I lost my vision.

Is there any history of eye conditions or diseases in your family?

**Final Diagnosis:** Transient Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (TION) or Amaurosis Fugax (AF) - this is a tentative diagnosis based on the given symptoms and requires further evaluation by a neurologist or ophthalmologist.

trial_3.summarized_frq: Transient Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (TION) or Amaurosis Fugax. These conditions are causes of sudden, painless vision loss, often described as a "curtain coming down" over the visual field. TION specifically affects the optic nerve, while Amaurosis Fugax is a transient ischemic attack affecting the retina or retinal artery. Both are forms of ischemic events in the eye.
